posts.cooked: My team recently got a CTRE CANdle that we intend to use for LEDs. We followed the provided documentation and it did not work as intended. Currently the CANdles built in LEDs display red, white, and pink of three of the LEDs, and the LED strip itself is a plethora of colors in an irregular pattern. By this I mean that half of the LEDs are off and the others are random colors. We are rather stumped because we followed the documentation and encountered errors. Any help would be greatly appreciated.

posts.name: Cole Wilson
posts.cooked:
Hello! Not sure if this will help but have you tried changing the LED strip type in your code? There are many different options like WRGB GBR etc. You can try setting it with candle.configLEDType(LEDStripType.*); If you are seeing “random” colors that might mean your code is sending out 4 bytes of data (WRGB) rather than 3 (RGB) or something like that.

Also, have you confirmed that you have the correct number of LEDs chosen if you are using any animations?

Finally, it’s also worth checking that any metal contacts on the back of external LED strips aren’t shorted. My team bought some LED lights for the CANdle and we accidentally shorted out a small section by sticking them on metal, causing “random” colors to appear further down the strip.

Thank you for the response! We are using CTRE Addressable LEDs that are GRB. We have them set to GRB in the code as well as in the config for the CANdle on Phoenix Tuner X.

I have currently not run any animations through, just solid colors. But I do not know how many segments are on the LED, which is definitely an issue. Is the segment count just how any LEDs are on the strip?

I will definitely make sure the first thing I do next meeting is check for shorts. It would really suck if this were the case because we just received them from CTRE yesterday, and today was the first time they have been used. I will look for shorts then check all the code, then ill test other LEDs.

Again thank you for the response, its very helpful to see all the ways we can trouble shoot this.

posts.name: Cole Wilson
posts.cooked: The segment count for the animations should be the number of LEDs on the strip + the 8 CANdle built-in LEDs I believe (the device treats external strips as an extension of the 8 onboard LEDs). Happy to help! I hope your team can get them working.

posts.name: SLAB-Mr.Thomas
posts.cooked:
Farquaad:

followed the provided documentation

We could check your work, if you had posted your code. Are you saying the CANdle LEDs are the wrong color even if no additional LEDS are attached? If you specify all LEDS to be the same color even the CANdle LEDs are not that color? What have you tried that works and what have you tried that doesn’t work?

I am using a code segment from another CD post that I modified to match our system.

As for the Candle before, It had the right half of the leads displaying three random colors. This was occurring before I added the segment of code to control them. The only thing that made the candle’s LED work was when the LED strip received power from two different areas, but this quickly heated the LEDs to a dangerous level and the LEDs themselves still had the issue.
Forgot to add this is how I am calling the LED methods to test the LEDs

posts.name: SLAB-Mr.Thomas
posts.cooked:
My team has struggled with the LEDs, too, and have these lessons including lesson from a couple of hours ago.

We bought some CTRE LEDs but bought a larger quantity of some from Amazon. They don’t look like it but are very fragile and we got breakage turning corners of the robot structure. We fixed the breaks and tested and had another break to fix.

If the CANdle isn’t working right with no LEDs plugged into it (except its internal ones) then that sounds like you are trying to use a 5 volt supply instead of the 12 v supply to the CANdle.

Consider possible CAN wiring trouble.

Needing an extra power supply on the LEDs and then overheating sounds like a break in the string and then using the wrong voltage boost to bypass the break or reverse polarity wiring errors.

Arrow on LEDs goes away from the CANdle as already mentioned.

The CANdle is rated for 6 A 5V output and our LED string was significantly less than that but the CANdle quit working. The next day it recovered but clearly the one we got can’t handle even 5 A on the 5 V output.

Make sure your LEDs are plugged into the right voltage. All of my team’s are 5V but I see 12V strings are available.

SLAB-Mr.Thomas:

If the CANdle isn’t working right with no LEDs plugged into it (except its internal ones) then that sounds like you are trying to use a 5 volt supply instead of the 12 v supply to the CANdle.

This was definitely one of the issues that was happening. We discovered that we were supplying it only 5v which is not good. Unfortunately we have not tested to see if this was the only issue but it seemed to make things better. There was also some CAN issues that were causing the CANdle to have connectivity issues.

Thank you so much for all of the help!

suggested_topics.title: Krackens and sensor suddenly not showing up
suggested_topics.excerpt: We found it after hours and hours. One of our zipties was pulled too tight, it cut into the casing of the wire. After we replaced it everything worked fine again.
